data.title: The 14 biggest comedy power couples in Hollywood
data.meta_description: These romantically linked funny men and women are killing it in the comedy world right now.
data.text:
This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? .

A number of Hollywood's best comedy talents are romantically connected.

Advertisement

Some enjoy separate gigs in acting, writing, producing, or hosting a talk show. Others combine their talents to make some of the funniest TV shows and movies in the business.

You may recognize several couples on Business Insider's list, such as comedian and talk show host Ellen DeGeneres and her wife, actress Portia de Rossi ("Arrested Development").

This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? .

And then there's the dynamic pairing of "Guardians of the Galaxy" star and hilarious "Parks and Recreation" alum Chris Pratt, and his wife, Anna Faris of "Mom" and "The House Bunny."

But some of these pairings will be a surprise. For example, did you know that Jordan Peele, half of the creative duo behind Comedy Central's "Key and Peele," is married to "Brooklyn Nine-Nine" funny woman Chelsea Peretti?

Advertisement

Take a look at these 14 hilarious pairs who are killing it in comedy:

Advertisement

Ben Falcone and Melissa McCarthy

Ben Falcone and Melissa McCarthy met in 1998 while studying sketch and improv with LA's The Groundlings. Falcone has been steadily working for years, with credits including "Joey," "A to Z," and "New Girl." McCarthy's career has been skyrocketing since starring on "Gilmore Girls" in the early-2000s and moving on to the big screen. Her biggest movies include "The Heat," "Bridesmaids," and the upcoming "Ghostbusters" reboot.

They see working together as an opportunity sidestep the hours typically spent away from your significant other on projects. They currently run their production company, On The Day.

Steve and Nancy Carell

"The Office" and "The 40-year-old Virgin" star Steve Carell met his wife, Nancy Carell (née Walls), when she was a student in his improv class at Chicago's Second City, and they married in 1995. They went on to work together on "Saturday Night Live," "The Daily Show," and "The Office." Most recently, they co-created the TBS comedy series "Angie Tribeca" starring Rashida Jones.

Advertisement

Samantha Bee and Jason Jones

Samantha Bee and Jason Jones met while working in children's theater. He went on to work at "The Daily Show with Jon Stewart" in 2001. She was performing as part of a sketch group before joining Jones on "The Daily Show" in 2003. Both decided to leave the show in 2015. Now, Bee hosts her own weekly commentary show on TBS called "Full Frontal." Meanwhile, Jones will star on the network's upcoming comedy, "Detour," which he and Bee created together.

Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi

Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi got married in 2008 after four years of dating. The queen of daytime television, DeGeneres is also an executive producer for NBC's new hit show "Little Big Shots," and "Ellen's Design Challenge" on HGTV. Currently, de Rossi appears on ABC's "Scandal," but she previously starred on the groundbreaking "Ally McBeal" and "Arrested Development."

Advertisement

Anna Faris and Chris Pratt

Anna Faris and Chris Pratt met while shooting "Take Me Home Tonight" in 2007. They got hitched two years later. She currently stars on the CBS comedy "Mom." He graduated from NBC's "Parks and Recreation" in 2015 and went on to star in the blockbusters "Guardians of the Galaxy" and "Jurassic World." Quickly making his name as a bona fide movie star, he'll act opposite Jennifer Lawrence in the sci-fi movie "Passengers" soon.

Megan Mullally and Nick Offerman

In 2000, multi-talented "Will & Grace" star Megan Mullally met comedian and "Parks and Recreation" actor Nick Offerman in LA during the reading for the play "The Berlin Circle." While dating, Offerman landed a guest role on "Will & Grace," in which his character kissed Mullally's Karen. In 2003, they invited a small group of friends over for a party. Upon arrival, their friends discovered they were there for the couple's wedding. Over the years, they've appeared together on Mullally's syndicated talk show, brought their voices to Adult Swim's "Childrens Hospital," and played exes on "Parks," among other projects.

Advertisement

Katie Aselton and Mark Duplass

Katie Eselton and Mark Duplass met at a New Year's Eve party in 2001. They tied the knot in 2006. The couple has worked together on several projects, notably FX's "The League," and some created by Duplass himself, including HBO's "Togetherness." She'll soon appear in a recurring role on the Hulu comedy "Casual."

Chelsea Peretti and Jordan Peele

Chelsea Peretti and Jordan Peele first chatted on Twitter and started dating in 2013. They got engaged in 2015. She's appeared on "The Kroll Show" and "Comedy! Bang! Bang!" and is now starring on Fox sitcom "Brooklyn-Nine-Nine." Peele is the cocreator and star of Comedy Central's "Key & Peele," and the 2016 movie "Keanu." From 2003 to 2008, he starred on the iconic sketch show "Mad TV."

Advertisement

Judd Apatow and Leslie Mann

Judd Apatow said it was love at first sight when Leslie Mann auditioned for "The Cable Guy" in 1996, which he cowrote and produced. They made their wedding vows the next year. The prolific Apatow has written, directed, and produced some of the most imaginative and popular comedy TV series and movies in the business, including HBO's "Girls," "The 40-Year-Old Virgin," "Knocked Up," and "Superbad." Mann has appeared in "The 40-Year-Old Virgin" and "Knocked Up," but viewers will also remember her in "The Other Woman" and 2015's "Vacation."

Cobie Smulders and Taran Killam

There isn't a lot of information about Cobie Smulders and Taran Killam's relationship before they were married in 2012. Smulders was a star of all nine seasons of "How I Met Your Mother," on which Killam made multiple guest appearances. He is also the only "Saturday Night Live" member to have also appeared on the sketch-comedy show "Mad TV."

Advertisement

June Diane Raphael and Paul Scheer

June Diane Raphael and Paul Scheer met when he was brought in to give her tips for a show she was working on with Casey Wilson ("Happy Endings"). They ended up marrying in 2009. Paul Scheer starred on FX's "The League." Meanwhile, Raphael has done movies "Forgetting Sarah Marshal," "Zodiac," and "New Girl." The duo also appeared in the movie "Bride Wars."

Kaitlin Olson and Rob McElhenney

"It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia" producer, writer, and actor Rob McElhenney met his future wife, actress Kaitlin Olson, when he cast her on the FX comedy. They began dating secretly about a year later and then married in 2008.

Advertisement

Andy Richter and Sarah Thyre

"Strangers with Candy" star Sarah Thyre met Conan O'Brien sidekick Andy Richter in 1992 when both were starring in a live production of "The Real Brady Bunch" in Los Angeles. Married in 1994, the couple has joined comedic forces on "Conan" sketches and both appeared on Comedy Central's "Upright Citizens Brigade."

David Cross and Amber Tamblyn

Comedian David Cross, 51, and actress Amber Tamblyn's May-December romance (she's 32) started when they sat next to each other on a flight. They married four years later in 2012. They both currently star on IFC's "The Increasingly Poor Decisions of Todd Margaret," which Cross created. He's best known for starring on "Arrested Development" and HBO's "Mr. Show." Tamblyn made her name in "The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants" movie franchise and TV shows "Two-and-a-Half Men" and "House MD."
